Admission Date:  [**2114-2-11**]     Discharge Date:

Date of Birth:   [**2079-2-4**]     Sex:  M

Service:  TRAUMA SURGERY

The patient is being transferred to Neurology service.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  This is a 35 year old male who
was initially brought to the Trauma Service by the [**Location (un) 86**]
police.  He was found hanging in his jail cell by a telephone
cord with estimated time of not breathing for ten minutes.
Apparently he stepped off a stool.  Initially on evaluation,
he was unresponsive and asystolic.  CPR was initiated at the
scene which resulted in regained pulses.  On transfer, it was
noted that he is breathing spontaneously.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:   Depression.

ALLERGIES:  Unclear.

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:
1.  Zyprexa.
2.  Ativan.
3.  Paxil.

FAMILY HISTORY: Noncontributory.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  He formerly worked in construction.  Unknown
tobacco history and unknown alcohol history.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  In trauma, he was unresponsive and
intubated.  The heart rate is 119, blood pressure is 221/140,
and he is intubated with oxygen saturation at 100%.  In
general, he is sedated, intubated.  The pupils are equal,
round, and reactive to light.  He does not open his eyes.
Trachea was in the midline.  The chest was clear to
auscultation bilaterally.  The heart has a regular rate and
rhythm with normal heart sounds without extra heart sounds.
The abdomen was soft and nondistended and no surgical scars.
The back has no step-off.  Rectal tone is normal and guaiac
negative.  The extremities were warm without obvious
deformities.  Neurologically, he is unresponsive, breathing
spontaneously.

LABORATORY DATA:  On admission, white blood cell count was
7.1, hematocrit 45.0 and platelet count 269,000.  Sodium 138,
potassium 4.6, chloride 103, bicarbonate 20, blood urea
nitrogen 17, creatinine 1.0.  His sugar level is 150 and his
coagulation studies were prothrombin time 12.8, partial
thromboplastin time 25.8 and INR 1.1.  Arterial blood gas was
obtained which showed a pH 7.33, pCO2 39. and pO2 174.
Toxicology screen was obtained which showed positive for
benzodiazepines.

The patient then subsequently received intubation and
transferred to the Trauma Surgery Intensive Care Unit for
Intensive care.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient essentially was staying in the
Trauma Surgery Intensive Care Unit from the day of admission
on [**2114-2-11**], during which a neurology consultation was
obtained and he was evaluated with several
electroencephalograms.  He was also evaluated by a brain
magnetic resonance scan on [**2114-2-13**], and then he is put on
tracheostomy and a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube
was placed on [**2114-2-26**].  He remained CPAP and feeding tube.
He is transferred on the 11th to the floor in stable
condition.  Subsequently, he is transferred to the Neurology
service on [**2114-4-11**].

The following is a system by system review of a brief
hospital course at the time of this dictation:
1.  Neurology - The patient upon admission to Intensive Care
Unit, Neurology service was consulted for unresponsiveness
and to evaluate possible brain ischemia.
Electroencephalogram was performed on [**2114-2-12**], which is
grossly abnormal and consistent with widespread cortical
dysfunction consistent with moderate encephalopathy.  This
was repeated [**2114-3-15**], which again showed mild widespread
cortical dysfunction.  Again, electroencephalogram is
repeated on [**2114-3-23**], which essentially showed no significant
improvement.  On physical examination neurologically, he was
initially unresponsive and on [**2114-2-18**], he was noted to be
spontaneously opening eyes and looked around but there was
posturing.  He was noted to have conjugated gaze at around
[**2114-3-22**], with the pupils equal and reactive to light and
increased tone in all four extremities and clonus in the
ankles bilaterally.  During [**Month (only) 547**], he had episodes of tongue
biting which responded to Ativan.  During the hospital stay,
he was put on Dilantin and was dosed accordingly.  On
[**2114-2-28**], it was noted question of seizure activity and over
the last month he is getting more and more responsive, now is
occasionally tracking people with gazing and seems to be able
to recognize family members and there is maybe occasions even
nodding yes and no for the last ten days or so.  However, he
does get very agitated and severely diaphoretic and was
trained to getting out of bed.  This was eventually treated
with Seroquel and Ativan and also was with restrictions.
Currently on the day of transfer, he is started with around
the clock Ativan and Seroquel.  Upon the suggestions of
Neurology service, we have been trying to decrease the Ativan
dose to p.r.n. and to continue Seroquel with possible
increased dose to decrease his level of agitation.  In late
[**Month (only) 116**], the patient seems to be having slight improvement in
neurological examinations and he is waiting for neurologic
rehabilitation placement partially for Medicaid approval and
it was decided that he is going to be benefited by being
transferred to Neurology service the end of [**Month (only) 116**].

2.  Respiratory - The patient has been intubated upon arrival
and was initially on SIMV for one day and then switched to
CPAP with pressure support subsequently.  He tolerated these
settings but there may be evidence of aspiration at the
beginning of his admission.  Sputum culture was consistent
with a respiratory tract infection, possible pneumonia, so on
[**2114-2-19**], he was started to be treated with Levaquin and
subsequently because blood culture grew out gram negative
rods on [**2114-2-22**], Vancomycin was started and then Gentamicin
was started two days later.  A tracheostomy tube was placed
around [**2114-2-26**], and he is being seen by the respiratory care
service subsequently.

3.  Cardiovascular - The patient when initially presented had
episodes of hypertension. Therefore, he was put on Labetalol
for blood pressure control.  During the hospitalization,
there is no issue of any cardiovascular distress.  Pulse rate
is consistently in the 80s to 90s and blood pressure has been
around 150s.

4.  Gastrointestinal - The patient was started on tube feeds
[**2114-2-16**], and a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube was
placed on [**2114-2-26**].  His tube feeds were gradually increased
with ProMod with Fiber in late [**Month (only) 116**] before transferring.  He
is tolerating tube feeds at 140 cc/hour.  Otherwise, he is on
gastrointestinal prophylaxis with proton pump inhibitors and
there are no other gastrointestinal issues.

5.  Endocrine - He has been checked with fingerstick and
covered appropriately with insulin sliding scale.  There is
no other endocrine issues.

6.  Renal - The patient has been on occasions observed to
have increased urine output which responded appropriately
with fluid bolus.  His blood urea nitrogen and creatinine
remained normal at approximately 0.6 on the day of transfer
[**2114-4-10**].  He has been found to have urinary tract infection
on [**2114-4-10**], and subsequently he was put on Levaquin.

7.  Infectious disease - As indicated above, the patient
initially showed symptoms of aspiration pneumonia.  Chest
x-ray showed left lower lobe consolidation which occurred
around late [**Month (only) 958**]. The patient was on Levaquin, Vancomycin
and Gentamicin until this was discontinued [**2114-3-2**].
Subsequently, the patient had episode of urinary tract
infection with approximately 50 white blood cells per high
power field on urinalysis.  So, he is started on Levaquin
around [**2114-4-9**].  On the day of transfer, he is still
receiving the Levaquin.

8.  Disposition - Apparently, in early times of admission, a
family meeting was held and it was decided to keep the
patient in full code.  The patient has been actively screened
for neurological rehabilitation facility which is also
pending Medicaid approval.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  This patient is to be transferred to
Neurology service around [**2114-4-11**].

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:  Central nervous system hypoxia
secondary to hanging.
